Time…|date=September 6, 2016|archivedate=September 6, 2016|website=Archive.today}} ==See also== {{Portal|Energy}} * [[India's three-stage nuclear power programme]] * [[India–United States relations]] * [[Energy policy of India]] * [[Nuclear Liability Act]] * [[Energy security]] * [[Foreign relations of India]] * [[Nuclear power in India]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== ;U.S. Government links * [http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=109_cong_bills&docid=f:h5682enr.txt.pdf U.S. Government Printing Office: The text of the Hyde Act] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080904052644/http://www.hcfa.house.gov/110/press090208.pdf U.S. House Foreign Affairs Committee: Questions for the Record submitted to Assistant Secretary Bernger by Chairman Tom Lantos] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080915215911/http://foreignaffairs.house.gov/press_display.asp?id=555 U.S. House Foreign Affairs Committee: Documents from the White House related to the U.S.-India civilian nuclear cooperation agreement] ;India Government links * [http://www.meaindia.nic.in/pressrelease/2007/08/03pr01.pdf Indian Ministry of External Affairs (August 2007): Text of the preliminary Indo-US nuclear agreement] (meaindia.nic.in) ;IAEA links * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100412130020/http://www.carnegieendowment.org/files/India_safeguards20080709.pdf IAEA Board of Governors. Nuclear Verification – The Conclusion of Safeguards Agreements and Additional Protocols : "An Agreement with the Government of India for the Application of Safeguards to Civilian Nuclear Facilities" (GOV 2008/30 of July 9, 2008).] ;Nuclear Suppliers Group links *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101120200023/http://www.armscontrol.org/system/files/20080906_Final_NSG_Statement.pdf Copy of Final NSG Agreement of September 6, 2008] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081121093937/http://www.nuclearsuppliersgroup.org/PRESS/2008-09-Press-Vienna.pdf ''Nuclear Suppliers Group'' (September 4–6 2008): NSG Public Statement – Extraordinary Plenary Meeting, Vienna] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090324202604/http://www.nuclearsuppliersgroup.org/PRESS/2008-AUG-Press-Vienna.pdf ''Nuclear Suppliers Group'' (August 21–22 2008): NSG Public Statement – Extraordinary Plenary Meeting, Vienna] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090324202606/http://www.nuclearsuppliersgroup.org/PDF/infcirc254r9p1-071107.pdf ''Nuclear Suppliers Group'' (November 2007): INFCIRC/254/Rev.9/Part 1] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090324202600/http://www.nuclearsuppliersgroup.org/PDF/infcirc254r7p2-060320.pdf ''Nuclear Suppliers Group'' (March 2006): INFCIRC/254/Rev.7/Part 2] ;Other links *[https://web.archive.org/web/20150211222128/http://www.teluguaspirant.com/civil-nuclear-liability-act-background-issues-cooperation-implementation/1642/ Indo-US nuclear agreement- basics] {{Nuclear power in India}} {{Foreign relations of India}} {{George W. {{Infobox mountain | name = Jengish Chokusu | photo = PobiedaFrmCB.jpg | photo_caption = Jengish Chokusu from the basecamp in [[Kyrgyzstan]] | map = Kyrgyzstan#China Xinjiang | map_caption = | location = [[Ak-Suu District]], [[Issyk-Kul Region]], Kyrgyzstan
[[Wensu County]], [[Xinjiang]], China | label_position = left | elevation_m = 7439 | elevation_ref = [http://www.peaklist.org/WWlists/ultras/StansP1500m.html "The Central Asian Republics: Ultra-Prominence Page"]. Peaklist.org. Retrieved 2014-05-26.
[[List of highest mountains|Ranked 60th]] | prominence_m = 4148 | prominence_ref=
[[List of peaks by prominence|Ranked 16th]] | listing = [[List of countries by highest point|Country high point]]
[[Ultra prominent peak|Ultra]] | range = [[Kakshaal Too]], [[Tian Shan]] | coordinates = {{coord|42|02|15|N|80|07|30|E|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | first_ascent = 1956 by [[Vitaly Abalakov]] | easiest_route = snow/ice climb | other_name = '''Pobeda Peak''' / '''Victory Peak''' }} '''Jengish Chokusu''' ({{lang-ky|Жеңиш чокусу}}, ''Ceñiş çoqusu'', جەڭىش چوقۇسۇ {{IPA-ky|dʒeŋiʃ tʃoqusú|}}; {{lang-ru|Пик Победы}}, ''Pik Pobedy'' {{IPA-ru|pʲik pɐˈbʲɛdɨ|}}) is the highest [[mountain]] in the [[Tian Shan]] mountain system at {{convert|7439|m|ft|0}}. It lies on the [[Kyrgyzstan]]–[[China]] border between [[Ak-Suu District|the raion of Ak-Suu]], in the [[Issyk-Kul Region]] of far eastern Kyrgyzstan and [[Wensu County]], [[Xinjiang]], China. It is part of the [[Kakshaal Too]], the highest part of the Tien Shan, and located southeast of lake [[Issyk Kul]]. == Names == The mountain's official name in [[Kyrgyz language|Kyrgyz]] is ''Jengish Choqusu'', which means "Victory Peak"; its [[Russian language|Russian]] name is '''''Pik Pobedy''''' (or Peak Pobeda) meaning the same. In [[Uighur language|Uyghur]], it is called '''''Tömür''''', which is also the official name of the mountain in China. The [[Chinese language|Chinese]] name '''''Tuōmù'ěr Fēng''''' ({{zh|s=托木尔峰|t=托木爾峰}}) is a combination of the Uighur ''tomur'', meaning 'iron' and Chinese ''feng'' meaning 'peak'. == Description == Jengish Chokusu is a massif, with several summits along its lengthy ridge. Only its main summit breaks 7,000 m. It is located {{convert|16|km|mi|abbr=on}} southwest of [[Khan Tengri]] (7,010 m / 22,998 ft), separated by the South [[Engilchek Glacier|Engilchek]] glacier, where base camps for both mountains are usually located. The massif runs at [[Angle#Types of angles|right angles]] to the glaciers which flow from it into three alpine valleys in Kyrgyzstan on the north, all eventually running to the [[Engilchek Glacier]], the largest in the Tian Shan. Its main summit is usually approached from the Zvozdochka (Russian for "little star") glacier, which is coloured red with rocks from Jengish Chokusu. Administratively, the Kyrgyzstan side of the mountain is in the [[Ak-Suu District]] of [[Issyk-Kul Region]], and the Chinese side, in [[Wensu County]] of the [[Aksu Prefecture]] of [[Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region]]. ==Records== [[Image:Stamp of Kyrgyzstan 232a.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Jengish Chokusu (Pobeda Peak) on a Kyrgyzstan stamp.]] Jengish Chokusu is the highest mountain in Kyrgyzstan. Jengish Chokusu is considered the most northerly 7,000-metre mountain in the world by geologists; the actual rock summit of [[Khan Tengri]], the Tian Shan's third highest peak, is 6,995m above sea level, though a thick layer of ice adds another 15m to its altitude, such that [[mountaineering|mountaineers]] classify it as 7,000m peak. The South Engilchek Glacier and its side glaciers occupy the entire north side of Peak Jengish Chokusu. This glacier, currently at 60.5 km in length, is the sixth longest outside of the world's polar regions.Tajikistan's Fedchenko Glacier is 77 km long, and the Karakoram's Siachen and Biafo Glaciers are 70 and 67 km long respectively. Measurements are from recent imagery, with Russian 1:200,000 scale topographic mapping for reference as well as the 1990 ‘’Orographic Sketch Map: Karakoram: Sheets 1 & 2’’, Swiss Foundation for Alpine Research, Zurich. ==History== [[File:Пик Победы 'Võidu mäetipp' 87.jpg|thumb|Peak seen in 1987. Photo by [[Jaan Künnap]].]] Although Jengish Chokusu is over 400 metres higher, [[Khan Tengri]] was believed to be the highest peak in the range until Jengish Chokusu's survey in 1946. A Soviet expedition mounted in 1938 to mark the 20th anniversary of the founding of the Communist Youth movement [[Komsomol]] claimed to have climbed the highest peak in the area, the summit being reached on September 19 by L.Gutman, E.Ivanov and A.Sidorenko. They measured the altitude as 6900 meters, and named the peak ''Pik 20-ti letiya Komsomola'' (Peak of the 20th Anniversary of Komsomol). A survey by another team in 1943 found the peak to be 7439 meters high. The peak was renamed as ''Pik Pobedy'' (Victory's Peak) in 1946 to commemorate the Soviet victory in [[World War II]]. The significant difference in altitude led to the 1938 ascent being called into question, although the official Soviet stand was to uphold the 1938 ascent.The Great Soviet Encyclopedia , 1979 A large-scale attempt on the peak in 1955 was disastrous, when 11 expedition members were killed in a blizzard.William Garner, 'High Road to 'Victory'" Soviet and U.S. Climbers conquer Pik Pobedy, ''National Geographic Magazine'', August 1986 (p.258) Jengish Chokusu's first indisputably verified ascent was in 1956 by [[Vitaly Mikhaylovich Abalakov|Vitaly Abalakov]]'s party.{{cite summitpost|id=151896|title=Pik Pobeda}} A Chinese expedition climbed the peak from the Chinese side in 1977: the expedition book makes no mention of the Russian first ascent and gives the impression that the Chinese ascent was the first climb.Planting the Five-Star Flag on Mount Tomur, Foreign Languages Press, Beijing, 1979 The first winter ascent of the peak was made by [[Valery Khrichtchatyi]] in February 1990.Chris Bonington, “Great Climbs”, p.206, {{ISBN|1-85732-573-7}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite magazine|title=High Road to "Victory"|first=William|last=Garner|magazine=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]|pp=256–271|volume=170|issue=2|date=August 1986|issn=0027-9358|oclc=643483454}} ==External links== * [http://mountains.tos.ru/breef.htm#pobeda Route maps] {{Highest points of Asia}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Mountains of Xinjiang]] [[Category:Mountains of Kyrgyzstan]] [[Category:China–Kyrgyzstan border]] [[Category:International mountains of Asia]] [[Category:Issyk-Kul Region]] [[Category:Aksu Prefecture]] [[Category:Highest points of countries]] [[Category:Seven-thousanders of the Tian Shan]]

[[File:Dr. Joseph J. Kerski .jpg|alt=Dr Joseph J. Kerski, geographer active in education and geotechnologies. |thumb|Dr Joseph J. Kerski, geographer active in education and geotechnologies. ]]
'''Joseph Kerski''' is a geographer<ref name="National Geographic">{{cite web |url=http://alliances.nationalgeographic.com/detail/night-with-a-geographer/ednA096316CA0305583F |title=Night with a Geographer – Network of Alliances for Geographic Education – National Geographic |newspaper=Alliances.nationalgeographic.com |date= |author= |accessdate= September 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gisuser.com/2015/12/10-question-geogeek-rapidfire-joseph-kerski-josephkerski/|title=10 Question GeoGeek Rapidfire – Joseph Kerski @josephkerski|website=gisuser.com|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.josephkerski.com/about-joseph-kerski/interview-with-the-primary-geographer/|title=Interview with "The Primary Geographer" – Joseph Kerski, Ph.D. - Geographer|newspaper=Joseph Kerski, Ph.D. - Geographer|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.esri.com/esri-news/releases/16-2qtr/ngtc-honors-esri-education-manager-lifetime-achievement-award|title=National Geospatial Technology Center Honors Esri Education Manager with Lifetime Achievement Award|website=www.esri.com|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref> with a focus on the use of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) in education.<ref name="Central">{{cite web |url=https://news.central.edu/news-release/iowa-gis-users-to-meet-at-central-college/ |title=Iowa GIS users to meet at Central College – Central College News |newspaper=Https: |date= |author= |accessdate= September 21, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Reuters">{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-map-idUSBRE94H03O20130518 |title=Amid frenzy over map apps, new focus on 16th century world view |newspaper=Reuters.com |date= |author= |accessdate= September 21, 2016}}</ref><ref name="CalGeography">{{cite web|url=https://calgeography.sdsu.edu/building-leadership-skills-geography-gis-education-notes-sdsu-colloquium-dr-joseph-kerski/|title=BUILDING LEADERSHIP SKILLS WITH GEOGRAPHY AND GIS EDUCATION: NOTES FROM THE SDSU COLLOQUIUM BY DR. JOSEPH KERSKI|first=|date=18 Feb 2015|website=calgeography.sdsu.edu |publisher=California Geographic Alliance |deadurl=no |accessdate=December 14, 2016}}</ref><ref name="SpaceAwareness">{{cite web |url=http://www.space-awareness.org/en/news/space-awareness-webinar-citizen-science-applied-education/ |title=Space Awareness Webinar: Citizen Science applied in Education |newspaper=Space-awareness.org |date= |author= |accessdate= September 21, 2016}}</ref><ref name="TaylorFrancis">{{cite web |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/19338341.2014.898209 |title=What's Wrong With This Picture? The Declining Water Table: The Geography Teacher: Vol 11, No 2 |newspaper=Tandfonline.com |date= |author= |accessdate= September 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.duprofessionaled.com/index.php/university-college-faculty-teaching-spotlight/|title=Faculty Teaching Spotlight – DU Professional Education|website=www.duprofessionaled.com|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref>
Joseph Kerski was the President of the [[National Council for Geographic Education]] in 2011.<ref name="Wisconsin State Cartographer's Office">{{cite web |url=http://www.sco.wisc.edu/wisconsin-geospatial-news/dr-joseph-kerski-to-deliver-keynote-at-2016-uw-madison-geospatial-summit.html |title=Dr. Joseph Kerski to deliver keynote at 2016 UW-Madison Geospatial Summit |newspaper=Sco.wisc.edu |date= |author= |accessdate= September 21, 2016}}</ref><ref name="IOWA Geographic Information Council">{{cite web |url=http://www.iowagic.org/about/who/committees/conference/keynote-speaker/ |title=Iowa Geographic Information Council (IGIC)Keynote Speaker – Joseph Kerski – Education Manager for ESRI – Iowa Geographic Information Council (IGIC) |newspaper=Iowagic.org |date= |author= |accessdate= September 21, 2016}}</ref><ref name="American Association of Geographers">{{cite web |url=http://www.aag.org/cs/jobs_and_careers/profiles_of_geography_professionals/kerski_joseph |title=Kerski, Joseph |newspaper=Aag.org |date= |author= |accessdate= September 21, 2016}}</ref> He is the author of the recent book ''Interpreting Our World''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc-clio.com/ABC-CLIOGreenwood/product.aspx?pc=A4544C|title=Interpreting Our World|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref> and is the co-author of the book ''The Essentials of the Environment''.<ref name="GIS and Science">{{cite web |url=https://gisandscience.com/2010/10/07/an-interview-with-joseph-kerski-co-author-of-the-essentials-of-the-environment/ |title=An Interview with Joseph Kerski, Co-author of “The Essentials of the Environment” |newspaper=Https: |date= |author= |accessdate= September 21, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Texas State">{{cite web |url=http://www.txstate.edu/news/news_releases/news_archive/2016/May-2016/Esri051116.html |title=In Brief: Geography Department honors Esri Education's Joseph Kerski : Office of Media Relations : Texas State University |newspaper=Txstate.edu |date= |author= |accessdate= September 21, 2016}}</ref>
He has served as geographers in 4 major sectors of society, including government (with NOAA, the US Census Bureau, and the US Geological Survey), academia (with Sinte Gleska University, the University of Denver, and as MOOC instructor for Penn State University, Elmhurst College, and eNet Learning), private industry (as Education Manager for Esri), and nonprofit organizations (with roles in the National Council for Geographic Education, the American Association of Geographers, and others).
Joseph Kerski has authored over 75 chapters and articles on Geographic Information Systems (GIS), education, physical and cultural geography, mathematics, fieldwork, teaching and learning, and related topics, and makes frequent presentations at conferences and university campuses. He is active in conducting professional development training for primary and secondary educators. He has authored or co-authored 7 books, including ''Interpreting Our World: 100 Discoveries that Revolutionized Geography, Essentials of the Environment, Spatial Mathematics, Tribal GIS, International Perspectives on Teaching and Learning in Secondary Education, and the GIS Guide to Public Domain Data.'' In 2018, he gave a presentation on the Whys of Where at TEDx Vail, focusing on [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cBEPZ1Yoirg the importance of mapping and geotechnologies in education and society.]
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{one source|date=June 2013}} This is a list of [[monarchy|monarchs]] who have reigned over the Pacific island of [[Niue]]. The island today is a self-governing territory in [[Associated state|free association]] with New Zealand, and recognises the [[Queen of New Zealand]] as monarch. Before this, however, the island previously had an indigenous monarchy, established around the beginning of the 18th century. Before that time, there appears to have been no national government or national leader in Niue. Chiefs and heads of family exercised authority over segments of the population. Around 1700, the concept and practice of [[kingship]] appears to have been introduced through contact with [[Samoa]] or [[Tonga]]. From then on, a succession of ''[[patu-iki]]'' (kings) ruled the island, the first of whom was Puni-mata. The monarch was non-hereditary; ''patu-iki'' were reportedly elected by the Niuean population, with the candidates being issued from influential families. As described by [[Percy Smith (ethnologist)|Percy Smith]] in 1903, Niue appears therefore to have been a [[democracy|democratic]] [[elective monarchy]]. ==List of ''patu-iki''== {| class="wikitable" width=100% ! width=150|Name ! width=100px|Portrait ! width=50|Birth ! width=50|Death ! width=50|Start ! width=50|End ! width=300|Notes |- |'''Puni-mata''' | |? |? |c. 1700 |? |He was the first ''patu-iki''. His death, of old age, was followed by an [[interregnum]] of significant but indeterminate length. |- |'''Patua-valu''' | |? |? |? |? |He was nominated for kingship by the population's elected choice, Tage-lagi, who declined the position and opted instead to be Patua-valu's lifelong bodyguard. Patua-valu died of old age. |- |'''Galiga''', also known as '''Galiaga-a-Iki''' and '''Galiaga of Palūki''' | |? |? |? |? |This ''patu-iki'' was murdered by a person called Tikomata. Following his death, Fakana-iki and Hetalaga vied to replace him, but failed to secure the approval of the population. Foki-mata eventually became the fourth ''patu-iki'' instead. He was the last king elected in times of peace. |- |'''Foki-mata''' | |? |1874? |? |1874? | |- |'''Pakieto''' | |? |1875? |1874? |1875? |He was ''patu-iki'' for only a year. Following his death, a war of succession occurred. He was one of the Tama-lagau people. |- |'''Tui-toga''', also known as '''Ta-tagata''' | |? |June 13, 1887 |March 2, 1885 |June 13, 1887 |The first Christian King of Niue. |- |'''[[Fata-a-iki]]''' |[[File:Fata-a-iki.jpg|100px]] |? |1896 |1887 (''de facto'')
November 21, 1888 (''de jure'') |1896 |The second Christian Niuean monarch. One of his first acts as ''patu-iki'' in 1877 was to send a letter to the [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|British monarch]] [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]], requesting that Niue be made a protectorate of the [[British Empire]], to protect the island from other imperial powers, although his letter (and another sent in 1895) received no replies. |- |'''[[Togia-Pulu-toaki]]''' |[[File:Tongia, King of Niue-Fekai.jpg|100px]] |? |? |1896 (''de facto'')
June 30, 1898 (''de jure'') |? |He was the king who finally ceded Niue to the British Empire on April 21, 1900, and who welcomed a Resident representative of the imperial government on Niue on September 11, 1901. Togia-Pulu-toaki remained ''patu-iki'' in 1903, when ''Niuē-fekai (or Savage) Island and its People'' was published and the date of his death, and whether or not he was succeeded, remains unclear. |} ==Imperial rule and free association== From 1900 to 1901, Niue was ruled by the United Kingdom. In 1901, the island was annexed by New Zealand, which administered it in the name of the British Empire. On 26 September 1907, New Zealand attained the status of [[British Dominions|dominion]], becoming the [[Dominion of New Zealand]], and the British monarch from then on reigned over Niue in his or her capacity as monarch of New Zealand. [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Elizabeth II]] was the first monarch to be explicitly titled [[Queen of New Zealand]], however, in 1952. Today, Niue is part of the [[Realm of New Zealand]], the successor political entity to the dominion. ===List of British monarchs reigning over Niue=== {{See also|List of British monarchs}} {| class="wikitable" width=100% ! width=100|Name ! width=100px|Portrait ! width=50|Birth ! width=50|Death ! width=50|Start ! width=50|End ! width=300|Notes |- |'''[[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Victoria]]''' |[[File:Queen Victoria by Bassano.jpg|100px]] |24 May 1819 |22 January 1901 |April 21, 1900 (''de facto'') |22 January 1901 | |- |'''[[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|Edward VII]]''' |[[File:Edward VII in coronation robes.jpg|100px]] |9 November 1841 |6 May 1910 |22 January 1901 |26 September 1907 | |} ===List of New Zealand monarchs reigning over Niue=== {{See also|List of New Zealand monarchs}} {{See also|Monarchy of New Zealand}} {| class="wikitable" width=100% ! width=100|Name ! width=100px|Portrait ! width=50|Birth ! width=50|Death ! width=50|Start ! width=50|End ! width=300|Notes |- |'''[[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|Edward VII]]''' |[[File:Edward VII in coronation robes.jpg|100px]] |9 November 1841 |6 May 1910 |26 September 1907 |6 May 1910 | |- |'''[[George V of the United Kingdom|George V]]''' |[[File:George V of the united Kingdom.jpg|100px]] |3 June 1865 |20 January 1936 |6 May 1910 |20 January 1936 | |- |'''[[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom|Edward VIII]]''' |[[File:Edward Prince of Wales during his visit to Canada in 1919.jpg|100px]] |23 June 1894 |28 May 1972 |20 January 1936 |11 December 1936 | |- |'''[[George VI of the United Kingdom|George VI]]''' |[[File:King George VI of England, formal photo portrait, circa 1940-1946.jpg|100px]] |14 December 1895 |6 February 1952 |11 December 1936 |6 February 1952 | |- |'''[[Elizabeth II]]''' |[[File:Elizabeth II greets NASA GSFC employees, May 8, 2007 edit.jpg|100px]] |21 April 1926 |''Living'' |6 February 1952 |''Incumbent'' | |} ==Sources== *S. Percy Smith, [http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/tei-SmiNiu.html ''Niuē-fekai (or Savage) Island and its People''], 1903, pp. 36–44 {{Niue topics}} {{Commonwealth realms}} {{Monarchies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Niuean Monarchs}} [[Category:History of Niue]] [[Category:Monarchy in New Zealand]] [[Category:Politics of Niue]] [[Category:Niue-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of monarchs|Niue]] [[Category:Niuean monarchs|*List]]

revision.text:
{{short description|The deepest part of the Atlantic Ocean – part of the Puerto Rico Trench}} {{Location map | Caribbean | lat_deg = 19 | lat_min = 35 | lat_sec = 0 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 66 | lon_min = 30 | lon_sec = 0 | lon_dir = W | label = Milwaukee Deep | label_size = | position = left | background = | mark = | marksize = 5 | width = 300 | float = | border = | caption = Location of Milwaukee Deep north of Puerto Rico | alt = | AlternativeMap = La2-demis-caribbean.png }} [[File:Caribbean-map.png|thumb|right|300px|Location map Puerto Rico trench - USGS]] [[File:Atlantic-trench.JPG|thumb|right|300px|Perspective view of the sea floor of the Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea. The Lesser Antilles are on the lower left side of the view and [[Florida]] is on the upper right. The purple sea floor at the center of the view is the Puerto Rico trench, the deepest part of the Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea.]] '''Milwaukee Deep''', also known as The Milwaukee Depth, ({{coord|19|35|N|66|30|W}}) is the deepest part of the [[Atlantic Ocean]] and is part of the [[Puerto Rico Trench]].<ref name="ucsd1">{{cite web|url=http://earthguide.ucsd.edu/earthguide/data/pdf/Appendix.pdf|title=Chart I. - Major Ocean Basins with Depths Exceeding 4000 meters (I-XLV)|author=Vaughn et. al|publisher=earthguide.ucsd.edu|date=1940|accessdate=2014-08-25}}</ref> It has a maximum depth of at least {{convert|27493|ft|m}}. It is just {{convert|76.0|mi|km}} north of the coast of [[Puerto Rico]] at ''Punto Palmas Altas'' in [[Manatí, Puerto Rico|Manatí]].<ref>"Milwaukee Depth". Encyclopædia Britannica. 2009. Encyclopædia Britannica Online. 12 October 2009 <http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/383165/Milwaukee-Depth>.</ref><ref name="mit1">{{cite web|url=http://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/handle/1721.1/75604/32418406.pdf?sequence=1|title=Low Cost Housing Development with Aided Self-Help Method in Bayamon, Commonwealth of Puerto Rico|author=Bulent Kastarlak|publisher=dspace.mit.edu|date=1958|accessdate=2014-08-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826120953/http://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/handle/1721.1/75604/32418406.pdf?sequence=1|archivedate=2014-08-26|df=}}</ref>
This ocean floor feature is named for the [[USS Milwaukee (CL-5)|USS ''Milwaukee'' (CL-5)]], a [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] [[Omaha class cruiser]], which discovered the Milwaukee Deep on February 14, 1939 with a reading of {{convert|28680|ft|m}}.<ref name="ucsd2">{{cite web|url=http://earthguide.ucsd.edu/earthguide/data/pdf/chapter2.pdf|title=Chapter II: The Earth and its Ocean Basins|author=Vaughn et. al|publisher=earthguide.ucsd.edu|date=1940|accessdate=2014-08-25}}</ref><ref name="WWII">{{cite book |last=Silverstone |first=Paul| title=The Navy of World War II: 1922-1947|year=2008}}</ref>
On August 19, 1952, the [[United States Fish and Wildlife Service|U.S. Fish and Wildlife]] vessel ''Theodore N. Gill'' obtained a reading of {{convert|28560|ft|m}} at ({{coord|19|36|N|68|19|W}}), virtually identical with the ''Milwaukee''{{'}}s reading.
The existence of deep water to the Atlantic Ocean side of the [[Caribbean]] has been known for more than a century. One of the area's earliest soundings was obtained June 12, 1852 by Lt. S. P. Lee, U.S. Navy [[brig]] [[USS Dolphin (1836)|''Dolphin'']], with a reading of {{convert|22950|ft|m}} at ({{coord|26|32|N|60|06|W}}).<ref>The Deepest Sounding in the North Atlantic, J. Lyman, Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A, Mathematical and Physical Sciences, Vol. 222, No. 1150, A Discussion on the Floor of the Atlantic Ocean (March 18, 1954), pp. 334–336. Published by: The Royal Society. <https://www.jstor.org/stable/99222></ref>
==See also==
*[[List of submarine topographical features]] *[[Oceanic trench]] *[[Challenger Deep]]
==References==
<references/>
[[Category:Extreme points of Earth]] [[Category:Oceanic trenches of the Atlantic Ocean]] [[Category:Physical oceanography]]

revision.comment: Copying from [[Category:17th-century English poets]] to [[Category:17th-century male writers]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
'''Nathanael Carpenter''' (1589–c. 1628) was an English [[author]], [[philosopher]], and [[geographer]].<ref>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Carpenter, Nathanael|volume=9}}</ref>
==Life==
He was son of [[John Carpenter (rector)|John Carpenter]], [[Rector (ecclesiastical)|rector]] of [[Northleigh]], [[Devon]], and was born there on 7 February 1589.<ref name="ACFSA">Alexander Chalmers, F.S.A., 1813, ''The General Biographical Dictionary: Containing An Historical and Critical Account of the Lives and Writings of the Most Eminent Persons in Every Nation; Particularly the British and Irish; from the Earliest Accounts to the Present Time'', revised and enlarged; Volume VIII, p. 273, gives his birth date as 7 February 1588 and states that he was born in [[Northlew|North-Lew]], [[West Devon]] [[district]] of the county of [[Devon]], "not [[Northleigh|Northlegh]]."</ref> He matriculated at [[St. Edmund Hall, Oxford]], on 7 June 1605; but was elected, on a recommendatory letter of [[James I]], a Devonshire fellow of [[Exeter College, Oxford|Exeter College]] on 30 June 1607. A second Devonshire candidate, Michael Jermyn, obtained an equal number of votes; the vice-chancellor gave his decision in favour of Carpenter. The dates of Carpenter's degrees were: [[Bachelor of Arts]] 5 July 1610, [[Master of Arts]] 1618, [[Bachelor of Divinity]] 11 May 1620, [[Doctor of Divinity]] 1626. During his residence at Oxford he is said to have become a noted philosopher, poet, mathematician, and geographer. One of his pupils at the university was [[Sir William Morice]], secretary of state 1660–8, a politician with religious views similar to his tutor's [[Calvinism]].
[[Matthew Sutcliffe]] nominated him a member of [[Chelsea College (17th century)|Chelsea College]], and Archbishop [[James Ussher]] brought him to Ireland, where he was appointed schoolmaster of the king's wards in [[Dublin]] (wards being minors of property whose parents were Roman Catholics). Carpenter's death is said to have occurred at Dublin in the beginning of 1628, and his funeral sermon was preached by [[Robert Ussher]].
==Works== His earliest work ''Philosophia libera triplici exercitationum decade proposita'' was an attack on the [[Aristotelianism|Aristotelian]] system of philosophy, and appeared at [[Frankfurt]] in 1621, under the pseudonym "N. C. Cosmopolitanus." Later editions were issued under his name in 1622, 1636, and 1675. His treatise of ''Geography Delineated Forth in Two Books'' was published in 1625, and republished in 1685. Three sermons entitled ''Achitophel, or the Picture of a Wicked Politician'', preached to the [[University of Oxford]] and dedicated to [[James Ussher]], are stated to have appeared in 1627, 1628, 1629, 1638, 1638, and 1642. The first edition was called in, and the passages against [[Arminianism in the Church of England|Arminianism]] were removed. After his death there appeared (1633 and 1640) a sermon, ''Chorazin and Bethsaida's Woe'', which he had preached at [[St. Mary's, Oxford]]. The dedication by N. H. was to [[Thomas Winniffe]], and asserts that but for a kinsman the manuscript might have been lost on the Dutch shores, as Carpenter's works on optics were in the Irish Sea.
==References== {{reflist}} * Madan, Falconer ''The Early Oxford Press: A Bibliography of Printing and Publishing at Oxford, 1468–1640'' ;Attribution *{{DNB|wstitle=Carpenter, Nathanael}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Carpenter, Nathanael}} [[Category:1580s births]] [[Category:1628 deaths]] [[Category:English writers]] [[Category:16th-century English poets]] [[Category:People of the Tudor period]] [[Category:People of the Stuart period]] [[Category:17th-century geographers]] [[Category:English philosophers]] [[Category:People from Devon]] [[Category:Fellows of Exeter College, Oxford]] [[Category:Alumni of St Mary Hall, Oxford]] [[Category:17th-century philosophers]] [[Category:17th-century English poets]] [[Category:17th-century male writers]] [[Category:17th-century English mathematicians]]

/* Port Jewish eidows in the Early modern period */ !
revision.text:
The '''Port Jew''' concept was formulated by [[Lois Dubin]] and [[David Sorkin]] in the late 1990s as a [[social type]] that describes Jews who were involved in the seafaring and maritime economy of Europe, especially in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Helen Fry suggests that they could be considered to have been "the earliest modern Jews."<ref name=HelenFry>{{cite journal |title=Port Jews: Jewish Communities in Cosmpolitan Maritime Trading Centres, 1550-1950 |first=Helen P. |last=Fry |journal=European Judaism |volume= 36|publisher=Frank Cass Publishers |year=2002 |ISBN=0-7146-8286-1|url=https://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst?docId=5002650793 |quote=Port Jews were a social type, usually those who were involved in seafaring and maritime trade, who (like Court Jews) could be seen as the earliest modern Jews. Often arriving as refugees from the Inquisition, they were permitted to settle as merchants and allowed to trade openly in places such as Amsterdam, London, Trieste and Hamburg. 'Their Diaspora connections and accumulated expertise lay in exactly the areas of overseas expansion that were then of interest to mercantilist governments.'}}</ref>
The concept of the "Port Jew" has been suggested as an "alternate path to modernity" that was distinct from the European [[Haskalah]]. Port Jews are described as the product of what is characterized as the "liberal environment" of port towns and cities.<ref>{{cite journal |first=C. S. |last=Monaco |title=Port Jews or a People of the Diaspora? A Critique of the Port Jew Concept |journal=Jewish Social Studies: History, Culture, Society |volume=15.2 |year=2009 |url=http://works.bepress.com/c_monaco/2}}</ref>
David Sorkin restricts his definition of the "port Jew" to apply only to a very specific group of Sephardi and Italian-Jewish merchants who were participants in the Mediterranean and transatlantic economy of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries.<ref name=Sorkin>{{cite journal |first=David |last=Sorkin |title=The Port Jew: Notes Toward a Social Type |journal=Journal of Jewish Studies |location=Cambridge, England |volume=50 |number=1 |date=Spring 1999 |pages=87–97}}</ref>
==Origins==
According to Helen Fry, Port Jews often arrived as "refugees from the Inquisition" and the expulsion of Jews from Iberia. They were allowed to settle in port cities as merchants granted permission to trade in ports such as Amsterdam, London, Trieste and Hamburg. Fry notes that their connections with the [[Jewish diaspora]] and their expertise in maritime trade made them of particular interest to the mercantilist governments of Europe.<ref name=HelenFry /> Lois Dubin describes Port Jews as Jewish merchants who were "valued for their engagement in the international maritime trade upon which such cities thrived".<ref>Dubin p. 47</ref> Sorkin and others have characterized the socio-cultural profile of these men as marked by a flexibility towards religion and a "reluctant cosmopolitanism that was alien to both traditional and "enlightened" Jewish identities."
== Port Jewish families and business in the early modern period == Jewish family tradition and strategy was built upon business and safety.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Davis|first=Natalie|year=1997|title=Religion and Capitalism Once Again? Jewish Merchant Culture in the Seventeenth Century|jstor=2928815|journal=University of California Press|volume=|pages=60–74|via=}}</ref> Jewish families, as in the case with the Jewish merchant Glikl, married off her children both in nearby cities as well as distant cities for the reason of business and safety.<ref name=":2" /> Glikl being a business woman was not uncommon amongst the German Jews. Christian, Italy, and France all differed from Jewish life history in that it was based on ethical will, which included more of a tale of life lessons to be passed on to the children as well as direction on how to proceed after their death.<ref name=":2" /> Glikl in writing her memoir focused on analyzing accounts of her life while simultaneously addressing her children.<ref name=":1" /> Not only was “[[Glückel of Hameln|Memoirs of Gluckel of Hameln]]” a rich source for cultural and social history, but it also had unusual literacy structure and religious resonance.<ref name=":1" /> In Jewish family culture ''koved'' was directly in tune with honesty in business which is also connected to your status, ''oysher un koved''.<ref name=":2" /> Glikl prided herself on leaving Hamburg without a bad debt with any jew or non jewish person. Jewish business failure held huge weight in bringing shame and disgrace to the Jewish name.<ref name=":2" />
=== Port Jewish widows in the early modern period === During the [[early modern period]], wives of [[Jewish history|Port Jew]] merchants participated in business through their approach of marriage as a business partnership.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Tallan|first=Cheryl|year=1991|title=Medieval Jewish Widows: Their Control of Resources|url=|journal=Jewish History|publisher=Springer|volume=5| issue = 1|pages=63–74}}</ref> Cheryl Tallan explains how earlier recordings of Jewish women partaking in their husbands’ business dealings can be witnessed in the case recorded by Rabbi Samson in 1216.<ref name=":0" /> During the seventeenth and eighteenth century, women such as [[Glückel of Hameln|Glickl of Hameln]], as read in the “[[Glückel of Hameln|Memoirs of Gluckel of Hameln]]”, (including both her mother and grandmother) participated in their husbands’ business dealings as Port Jews in Hamburg.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=acls;idno=heb01639|title=Women on the Margins|last=Zemon Davis|first=Natalie|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=1995|isbn=0674955218|location=Boston|pages=5–72|quote=|via=University of Michigan E-Book}}</ref> As was common with many Jewish couples during this period, women had the opportunity to continue their family business after their husbands were deceased.<ref name=":1" /> As a widow, they received a dowry from their husbands upon their husbands’ death.<ref name=":0" /> Through the dowries, Jewish widows were able to continue their husbands’ business dealings and their children’s marriage proposals through the utilization of the business networks established prior to their husbands’ death.<ref name=":1" />
==Expanded to include Ashkenazi merchants==
Dubin has proposed that the concept of the "port Jew" be expanded to describe "port Jewry" which she describes as a particular type of Jewish community that existed in European maritime ports and combined maritime commerce with European and Jewish culture. This expanded definition would encompass Ashkenazi as well as Sephardi merchants living in other European ports such as Hamburg, Southampton, Portsmouth, and Odessa.
==See also== *[[Jewish pirates]] *[[Radhanite]] *[[Middleman minority]]
==Sources== *{{cite journal |first=David |last=Sorkin |title=The Port Jew: Notes Toward a Social Type |journal=Journal of Jewish Studies |location=Cambridge, England |volume=50 |number=1 |date=Spring 1999 |pages=87–97}} *Dubin, Lois. ''The Port Jews of Habsburg Trieste: Absolutist Politics and Enlightenment Culture.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 1999 *Cesarani, David ed. ''Port Jews: Jewish Communities in Cosmopolitan Maritime Trading Centres, 1550–1950.'' London: Frank Cass, 2002 *Cesarani, David and Romain, Gemma eds. ''Jews and Port Cities, 1590–1990: Commerce, Community and Cosmopolitanism.'' London: Vallentine Mitchell, 2006 *Monaco, C. S. “Port Jews or a People of the Diaspora? A Critique of the Port Jew Concept,” In ''Jewish Social Studies'' Vol. 15, no. 2 (Winter 2009), pp. 137–66
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=August 2009}}
In [[statistics]], a '''ranklet''' is an orientation-selective non-parametric feature which is based on the computation of [[Mann–Whitney U|Mann–Whitney–Wilcoxon]] (MWW) rank-sum test statistics. Ranklets achieve similar response to [[Haar wavelet]]s as they share the same pattern of orientation-selectivity, multi-scale nature and a suitable notion of completeness.
Rank-based (non-parametric) features have become popular in the field of [[image processing]] for their robustness in detecting outliers and invariance to monotonic transformations such as brightness, contrast changes and [[gamma correction]].
The [[Mann–Whitney U|MWW]] is a combination of [[Wilcoxon signed-rank test|Wilcoxon rank-sum test]] and Mann–Whitney U-test. It is a non-parametric alternative to the [[Student's t-test|t-test]] used to test the hypothesis for the comparison of two independent distributions. It assesses whether two samples of observations, usually referred as Treatment '''''T''''' and Control '''''C''''', come from the same distribution but do not have to be normally distributed.
The Wilcoxon rank-sum statistics ''W''<sub>''s''</sub> is determined as:
: <math>W_s=\sum^N_{i=1}\pi_i V_i \text{ where }\pi_i = \text{rank of element }i\text{ and }V_i = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{ for }\pi_i\in C \\[3pt] 1 & \text{ for }\pi_i\in T \end{cases} </math>
Subsequently, let ''MW'' be the Mann–Whitney statistics defined by:
: <math>MW=W_s-\frac{m(m+1)}{2}</math>
where ''m'' is the number of Treatment values.
A ranklet ''R'' is defined as the normalization of ''MW'' in the range [−1, +1]:
: <math>R = \frac{MW}{mn/2}-1</math>
where a positive value means that the Treatment region is brighter than the Control region, and a negative value otherwise.
==Example== Suppose <math>T=\lbrace 5,9,1,10,15\rbrace </math> and <math>C=\lbrace 20,4,7,13,19,11\rbrace</math> then <center> {| class="wikitable" |- | '''Intensity''' | <center>1</center> | <center>4</center> | <center>5</center> | <center>7</center> | <center>9</center> | <center>10</center> | <center>11</center> | <center>13</center> | <center>15</center> | <center>19</center> | <center>20</center> |- | '''Sample''' | <center>T</center> | <center>C</center> | <center>T</center> | <center>C</center> | <center>T</center> | <center>T</center> | <center>C</center> | <center>C</center> | <center>T</center> | <center>C</center> | <center>C</center> |- | '''Rank''' | <center>1</center> | <center>2</center> | <center>3</center> | <center>4</center> | <center>5</center> | <center>6</center> | <center>7</center> | <center>8</center> | <center>9</center> | <center>10</center> | <center>11</center> |} </center> *<math>W_s=\Big\lbrace 1+3+5+6+9\Big\rbrace =24</math> *<math>MW=24-[5 \times (5+1)/2]=9</math> *<math>R=[9/[5 \times 6/2]]-1=-0.4</math>
Hence, in the above example the Control region was a little bit brighter than the Treatment region.
==Method== Since Ranklets are non-linear filters, they can only be applied in the spatial domain. Filtering with Ranklets involves dividing an image window ''W'' into Treatment and Control regions as shown in the image below:
[[Image:Ranklets.png|center|400px|Orientation-Selective Ranklets]]
Subsequently, Wilcoxon rank-sum test statistics are computed in order to determine the intensity variations among conveniently chosen regions (according to the required orientation) of the samples in ''W''. The intensity values of both regions are then replaced by the respective ranking scores. These ranking scores determine a pairwise comparison between the '''''T''''' and '''''C''''' regions. This means that a ranklet essentially counts the number of '''T'''x'''C''' pairs which are brighter in the '''''T''''' set. Hence a positive value means that the Treatment values are brighter than the Control values, and vice versa.
==External links== * [[Matlab]] [https://web.archive.org/web/20110722070312/http://www.cs.rug.nl/~george/RankletFilter.m RankletFilter.m -> source file to decompose an image into Intensity Ranklets]
<!-- [[Matlab]] [http://www.cs.rug.nl/~george/BMVC2009/rankletDecomposition.m rankletDecomposition.m -> source file to decompose an image into Intensity and Variance Ranklets] [[Matlab]] [http://www.cs.rug.nl/~george/BMVC2009/rankFilter.m rankFilter.m -> source file to compute intensity and variance ranklets] -->
[[Category:Nonlinear filters]] [[Category:Nonparametric statistics]] [[Category:Spatial data analysis]]

{{Infobox lake |name=Sawa Lake |image=Sawa lake Iraq.jpg |caption= |image_bathymetry= |caption_bathymetry= |location = [[Muthanna Governorate]], [[Iraq]] |coords={{coord|31|18|46.3|N|44|57|36.6|E|region:Iq|display=inline,title}} |lake_type = [[Endorheic basin]] |inflow = |outflow = |catchment = |basin_countries = |length = {{convert|4.74 |km|abbr=on}} |width = {{convert|1.77|km|abbr=on}} |area ={{convert|12.5|km2|abbr=on}} |depth = |residence_time = |max-depth = |volume = |shore = |elevation = |islands = |cities = |frozen = |reference = |embedded = {{Designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = Ramsar | designation1_offname = Sawa Lake | designation1_date = 3 March 2014 | designation1_number = 2240<ref name="RSIS">{{Cite web|title=Sawa Lake|website=[[Ramsar Convention|Ramsar]] Sites Information Service|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/2240|accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref>}} }} {{Location map|Iraq|label= |marksize=6|mark=Red_pog.svg |lat_dir=N |lat_deg=31|lat_min=18|lat_sec=46.3 |lon_dir=E|lon_deg=44|lon_min=57|lon_sec=36.6 |position=right|width=230|float=right |caption=Location of Sawa Lake }}
'''Sawa Lake''' ({{lang-ar| بحيرة ساوة}}) is an [[Endorheic basin]] located in the Iraqi governorate of [[Muthanna Governorate|Muthanna]] near to the [[Euphrates]] River, some {{convert|23|km}} to the west of [[Samawah|Al-Samawa]] city. This lake has no inlet or outlet, but it draws water from the Euphrates through a system of joint cracks and fissures which transport water to aquifers beneath it. The water's level fluctuates during dry and wet seasons but does not dry up because of the equilibrium state between water feed and evaporation.
==Description== Lake Sawa is a unique body of water in Iraq since characterized by highest salinity value (up to 35 g/l as TDS)<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Boschetti|first=Tiziano|last2=Awadh|first2=Salih Muhammad|last3=Salvioli-Mariani|first3=Emma|date=2018|title=The Origin and MgCl2–NaCl Variations in an Athalassic Sag Pond: Insights from Chemical and Isotopic Data|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10498-018-9337-y|journal=Aquatic Geochemistry|language=en|volume=24|issue=2|pages=137–162|doi=10.1007/s10498-018-9337-y|issn=1380-6165|via=}}</ref> among Iraqi inland bodies water. Chemical and isotope analyses revealed its meteoric origin and a confirm a main feeding from the ascending groundwater from the lake bottom via joints, cracks, and fissure systems.<ref name=":1" /> The lake has longitudinal shape with 4.47 km, long and 1.77 km wide.The water level in the lake is one of the manifestations of the lake, which gives something of aesthetic and strangeness. Strangeness reflected the fact that the water level in the lake is higher than the adjacent land around the lake by 1–4 meters . Add to that, the water level of the lake is also higher than the water level of the Euphrates River by 5–7 meters which flow near the lake to the east side and the Shat Al-Arab and [[Persian Gulf]] by 17–20 m.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.iasj.net/iasj?func=fulltext&aId=110919|title =Bull. Iraq nat. Hist. Mus.|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> A formations of gypsum are surrounding the lake, in some cases these a gypsum formations reach 6 m tall. They are formed due to evaporation of salty water and sedimentation of salt in shallow banks of lake.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.iasj.net/iasj?func=fulltext&aId=86984|title = Iraqi Academic Scientific journal|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> A formations of gypsum works as a dam prevent water flow from the lake on surrounding areas.
==Climate== Sawa Lake is characterized by arid climate. Highest and lowest temperatures are ranges between (27.6– 44.6) °C. Mean annual rainfall is 110 mm per year, highest values of evaporation occur during July (506 mm) while lowest values occurring in January (89 mm). Overall wind direction is a North-West with speed of 4.1 m/s. <ref>Iraqi Meteorological Organization., 2012: Climate data of recorded in Al-Sammwa station forperiod from (1990-2011)</ref>
==Flora and fauna== Because of its saline water, no plants grow in the lake or on its shores. [[Fish]] and [[algae]] are the most important aquatic organisms. One kind of fish lives in Sawa Lake, the [[Arabian toothcarp]] of the genus ''[[Aphanius]]'', [[Pupfish|Cyprinodontidatae]] family, characterized by its soft appearance, small size (they do not exceed 10 cm), and eyes that quickly disappear after death. Also there are ''[[Pomatiopsis|Pomatiopsis tryon]]'' which is [[Gastropoda|Gastropoda genus]] and lives in brackish water from [[Oligocene|Oligocene age]] to recent times, particularly on the lake bottom.
Unlike its scarcity of aquatic organisms, Sawa Lake is rich with birds; 25 species of resident and immigrant birds were observed in Sawa Lake and the surrounding areas. the lake held large numbers of [[waterfowl]], mainly [[duck]]s and [[Eurasian coot|coot]] (''Fulica atra''). The endemic race of [[little grebe]] (''Tachybaptus ruficollis iraquensis'') and the [[Mesopotamian crow]] (''Corvus cornix capellanus'') occur, as well as the near-endemic [[grey hypocolius]]. Locals and hunters reported the frequent occurrence of “different kinds of raptors” especially in spring and autumn, so the site may be important as a staging area.
The desert area on the western side of the lake, the fresh wetland strip (represented by the western branch of Euphrates River including the orchards), and the flat arid/semi-desert areas over the southern parts of the lake might harbor considerable wildlife diversity, mammals present include [[Rüppell's fox]], [[striped hyena]] (near-threatened), [[honey badger]], and [[Indian gray mongoose]] (''Herpestes edwardsii''). Reptiles found included: Water snake (maybe Natrix tessellata).<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://www.natureiraq.org/uploads/9/2/7/0/9270858/sawa_lake_mt1_22_mar-anna.pdf|title = Sawa Lake and the surrounding area (MT1)|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
==Environmental Concerns== As Sawa Lake represents a unique, closed water body in Iraq it is an important site to protect for its scientific, educational and biodiversity value. Only human intrusion was considered a high threat because Sawa Lake is the only water body available for the city of Samawa and its surroundings. It is a popular picnic area but this has caused a great deal of garbage accumulation everywhere around the lake. There appears to be no effort by visitors or government to manage or remove garbage from the site. Because there is no plant cover on the lake (reed beds, etc.), water birds have few places to shelter from visitors or hunters. Three threats were classified as ‘high’:urban expansion (the team was informed that the lake area was submitted for an investment project which might involve new construction around the lake); hunting, primarily represented by fishing (mainly netting) and hunting of birds, and pollution caused by the frequent visitors. Other threats (agriculture, resource extraction, transportation & service corridors, and natural systems modification) were considered ‘low’.<ref name=":0" /> The lake has been designated as a protected [[Ramsar site]] since 2014.<ref name="RSIS"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://wikimapia.org/#lang=en&lat=31.312875&lon=44.960175&z=12&m=b Map of Sawa Lake]

{{Infobox mountain | name = Thabana Ntlenyana | photo = | photo_caption = | photo_size = | elevation_m = 3482 | elevation_ref = | prominence_m = 2390 | prominence_ref = | map = Lesotho | map_caption = Location of Thabana Ntlenyana in Lesotho | map_size = 250 | label_position = left | listing = [[List of countries by highest point|Country high point]]
[[Ultra prominent peak|Ultra]] | location = [[Lesotho]] | range = [[Drakensberg]] | coordinates = {{coord|29|28|S|29|16|E|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | topo = | type = | age = | first_ascent = | easiest_route = [[Hiking|Hike]] }} '''Thabana Ntlenyana''', which literally means "Beautiful little mountain" in [[Sesotho]], is the highest point in [[Lesotho]]{{cite web|last=Sommer|first=Chris|title=Roof of the Maloti|url=http://www.vertical-endeavour.com/lesotho/60-peaks/84-roof-maloti-drakensberg.html}} and the highest [[mountain]] in southern [[Africa]]. It is situated on the [[Mohlesi]] ridge of the [[Drakensberg]]/[[Maloti Mountains]], north of [[Sani Pass]]. It stands at {{convert|3482|m|ft|0}} high. The peak is usually climbed by groups completing a Grand Traverse of the Drakensberg, although the peak is technically in the Maloti Mountains.{{cite web|last=Sommer|first=Chris|title=Grand Traverse|url=http://www.vertical-endeavour.com/drakensberg/29-grand-traverse/7-what-is-grand-traverse.html}} The peak is often also climbed from [[Sani Top Chalet]] or from [[Vergelegen Nature Reserve]].{{cite book|title=Geo Maps Series Map 5}} [[File:Thabana Ntlenyana from Giants Ridge.jpg|thumb|281x281px|Thabana Ntlenyana as seen from the Giants Castle Ridge]] ==Resources== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111005204028/http://www.feow.org/ecoregion_details.php?eco=574 Fresh Water Ecoregions of the World] * [http://www.govertical.co.za Guided Trekking of Thabana Ntlenyana] == References == {{Refimprove|date=May 2016}} [[Category:Drakensberg]] [[Category:Highest points of countries]] {{Lesotho-geo-stub}}

{{Infobox lake | name = Veliko Blato
Велико Блато | image = Borca.jpg | caption = Aerial view of Borča with Veliko Blato in the distance | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = | coords = {{coord|44.862759|N|20.494819|E|type:waterbody|display=inline|name=Veliko Blato}} | type = | inflow = none | outflow = none | catchment = | basin_countries = Serbia | length = | width = | area = {{convert|1.8|km2|abbr=on}} | depth = | max-depth = {{convert|1.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | islands = | cities = Belgrade }} '''Veliko Blato''' ({{lang-sr|Велико Блато}}) is a lake in [[Krnjača]],{{cite web|url= http://www.politika.rs/sr/clanak/355056/Jedinstvene-divlje-orhideje-u-Velikom-blatu-Palilule|author=Branka Vasiljević|title= Jedinstvene divlje orhideje u Velikkom blatu Palilule|date=15 May 2016|publisher=[[Politika]]|language=Serbian}} an urban neighborhood of [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]]. It is located in the municipality of [[Palilula, Belgrade|Palilula]]. == Location == The lake is located in the northern section of Krnjača, {{convert|10|km|abbr=on}} north of downtown Belgrade. It is positioned at the tripoint of the neighborhoods of [[Borča]], [[Ovča]] and Krnjača. ==Geography== Veliko Blato is situated in the southern part of the [[Pančevački Rit]] marshland. The lake is generally heart-shaped and covers an area of {{convert|1.8|km2|abbr=on}} or {{convert|2|km2|abbr=on}} with the adjoining fish ponds. It is the largest body of water in the Pančevački Rit, though it is shallow, as the maximum depth is only {{convert|1.5|m|abbr=on}}. The area of the entire protected zone which surrounds the lake, and includes four [[fish pond]]s to the north, is {{convert|3|km2|abbr=on}}. The lake is embedded in the depression between the [[reed (plant)|reed covered]] wet floodplains. The lake has no inflows or outflows, though the entire northern part is encircled by the [[Sebeš]] canal and another canal closely engulfs the entire lake. Water is replenished from the Danube and through the underground springs. The name of the lake means "great [[mudflat]]" in Serbian. == Wildlife == === Plants === In and around the lake there are 191 plant species, out of which 14 are protected. Since 1865, when [[Josif Pančić]] found the first specimen, 30 species of orchids have been registered on the territory of the City of Belgrade. Two of them can be found only in Veliko Blato. One is [[marsh helleborine]] (Epipactis palustris (L.) Cr.), with some 200 individual plants. It grows only up to {{convert|20|m|abbr=on}} from the canal which encircles the lake. It was discovered near the lake in 2012. The other, with only some 50 specimens, is [[Orchis palustris]] Jacq. It grows between the turfs of grass where the water has dug minute canals. It was spotted for the first time in Belgrade in 1896 on the [[Great War Island]], but was never seen again there. It has been re-discovered in the [[Makiš]] area in 1955, but by 2001 it disappeared, too.{{Citation | last = | first = | author = Beta| title = Uskoro zaštita staništa orhideja u Beogradu | newspaper = [[Politika]] | pages = | language = Serbian | date = 29 June 2013 | url = }}{{Citation | last = | first = | author = Branka Vasiljević | title = Retka orhideja u Krnjači | newspaper = [[Politika]] | pages = | language = Serbian | date = August 2012 | url = }} === Animals === One species of fish, [[European weatherfish]], is protected. Other of the 15 species of fish include [[carp]], [[northern pike]], [[wels catfish]], [[zander]] and [[silver carp]], though they are introduced later. There are also 9 species of amphibians and 4 species of reptiles. The lake is suitable for [[newts]], [[frogs]], [[lizards]], [[grass snakes]] and [[dice snakes]]. Veliko Blato is inhabited by 120 species of birds. There is a mixed colony of heron species which consists of [[little egret]]s, [[squacco heron]]s, [[grey heron]]s, [[night herons]] and [[purple heron]]s. The colony was discovered only in June 2013 and is the only nesting heron colony on the urban territory of Belgrade, with several dozens of nesting couples. Other birds include [[Eurasian coot]], [[great cormorant]], [[pygmy cormorant]], [[Caspian gull]], [[black-headed gull]], [[diving duck]], [[common pochard]], [[mallard]], [[tufted duck]]. Largest European eagle, [[white-tailed eagle]], nests in the other parts of Belgrade (Great War Island, [[Ada Huja]]), but feeds in the area. The lake is an internationally important area for the bird protection. == Human interaction == "Mika Alas", carp-breeding fish pond was established in 1961, when the lake was populated with many fish species. Veliko Blato is used as a [[feedlot]] for the larger fish. Four basins (including two fry ponds ), north of the lake, are built as a part of the fish pond. The lake is used for the [[sports fishing]] and all the fish that has been caught, must be released back into the lake. Every year, after the fishing season is over, the smaller basins are being emptied. In the early 2010s, an [[illegal dumping]] created a landfill south of the lake, which hastened the procedure of placing the lake under protection. Veliko Blato is not suitable for swimming and bathing due to the large quantities of mud in it. == Protection == Veliko Blato is a high valuable biotope, especially given its vicinity to the big city. It is part of an ecological area "Sava's mouth into the Danube" and due to its importance for the nesting, migration and wintering of the birds, it has been declared an [[Important Bird Area]]. It has been officially protected by the city government in May 2017, in the status of the "protected habitat".{{cite web|url= https://www.lobi-info.rs/jezero-veliko-blato-postaje-zasticeno-staniste/|author=M.K. |title= Veliko blato postaje zaštićeno stanište |date=5 May 2016 | publisher= Leva Obala Beograda Info|language=Serbian}} == References == {{reflist}} {{coord|44.862759|N|20.494819|E|display=title}} [[Category:Geography of Belgrade]] [[Category:Lakes of Serbia]] [[Category:Wetlands of Serbia]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=May 2016}} '''Wainamah''' is one of 33 villages in the town of [[Jakiri]], [[Cameroon]]. It is the second village into Jakiri from [[Bamenda]]. It is located along the Ring Road in the North West Region of Cameroon, on a hill. It is bounded by Babessi town in Ngoketuja Division and villages like Sarkong, Ntseimban, Waarin, Limbo and Kwansoh.
==History== The name ''Wainamah'' comes from the [[Nso language]] (lamnso). ''Wai Namah'' is literally translated as "tobacco market". The name stems from the first settlers of the area who were cultivating and selling tobacco. They then became numerous that the area grew into a village.
==Geography and climate==
Wainamah is located some 78 km from Bamenda and 1802 km above sea level. This village experiences alternative wet season of about eight(8) months from Mid March and dry season of about four (4) months from Mid November. The village is characterized by very low temperatures with a continuous gentle breeze as it is located on a hill top. Highest temperatures recorded here ranges between 18oc– 21.80 c around March. Temperatures can go as low as 10.4o between August and September.
==Education==
There is a government High school (G H S) at Wainamah and one Government Primary school.
==Economy==
Agriculture is the backbone of the economy of Wainamah village. Though the name 'Wainamah' means 'tobacco market', it is a bit difficult to find tobacco in the area. This is because of the decline in the price of the tobacco years back, new farms and modern methods of cultivation by the companies that used to buy the local tobacco from these villagers, thus, the new generation here does not find it worthy to cultivate the tobacco since it is mainly for export, consumed by a very few aged people. The abandonment of tobacco cultivation led to peasant agriculture with main crops like maize, beans, cassava, palm wine tapping and cattle rearing. Wainamah has the second largest cattle market in Bui Division with a slaughter slap provided by the state. The villagers of Wainamah take advantage of the long rainy season which ensures continuous availability of grass and legumes for animals to rear a good number of cattle, goats and sheep.
The cold temperatures slow down agricultural activities as crops such as maize which is one of the main crops cultivated here take up to 7–8 months to mature. This forces the villagers to take up farms in the neighboring villages like Kwanso or Babessi town.
There also exist a few shops in the village. Here, bars or drinking spots of either mix of industrially brewed drinks and palm wine or exclusive palm wine spots which outnumber the industrially brewed drinks spots.
==Administration and politics==
Wainamah, a village in Jakiri is under the control of a Divisional officer for Jakiri Sub Division administratively and The Mayor of Jakiri. The inhabitants of Wainamah actively participate in politics. Though there are numerous political parties in [[Cameroon]], only two – the Social Democratic Front (S.D.F) of [[Ni John Fru Ndi]] and the Cameroon's People Democratic Movement (C.P.D.M) as of 2016 It is place under direct supervision of a councilor (Jakiri counsel Agent).
==Health== Wainamah has a Health Center that is headed by a chief of center and managed by a doctor based in Jakiri (Mantung Hospital) the hospital serves about 5276 inhabitants of the village including villagers from other neighboring villages. There are about 12 beds in the Health center and 3 nurses (2016).
==Religion==
The inhabitants of Wainamah belong to two religions: Christianity and Islam. This is indicated by the presence of churches like The Cameroon Baptist Convention (CBC), the Apostolic Church, and the Mosque.
